answer_html: \(\mathbf{x}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} +s \begin{bmatrix} -2\\ -2\\ 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} +t \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}.\) There are an infinite number of solutions.
answer_latex:
$\mathbf{x}=\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
+s
\begin{bmatrix}
-2\\
-2\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
+t
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}.$ There are an infinite number of solutions.
hints_html: When we have more columns that rows in a matrix, what do we know about the number of free variables?
hints_latex:
When we have more columns that rows in a matrix, what do we know about
the number of free variables?
hints_raw: When we have more columns that rows in a matrix, what do we know about the number of free variables?
question: B 04 (e)
sols_html:
For the matrix,

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cccc}1 & 0 & 2 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 2 & -2 \end{array}\right.\left| \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

we have two more columns than rows (the matrix is rank deficient) and so we have two free variables. Let x3 and x4 be those variables. Then from row 2 we have,

\[\begin{aligned} x_2+2x_3-2x_4&=2\\ x_2&=2-2x_3+2x_4\end{aligned}\]

and from row 1 we have,

\[\begin{aligned} x_1+2x_3-x_4&=1\\ x_1&=1-2x_3+x_4.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we have two null vectors,

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} -2\\ -2\\ 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

as well as a particular solution

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore the solution is

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} +s \begin{bmatrix} -2\\ -2\\ 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} +t \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

There are an infinite number of solutions.
sols_raw:
For the matrix,

:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cccc}1 & 0 & 2 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 2 & -2 \end{array}\right. \left| \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right]
</math>

we have two more columns than rows (the matrix is rank deficient) and so we have two free variables.  Let ''x''<sub>3</sub> and ''x''<sub>4</sub> be those variables.  Then from row 2 we have,

:<math>
\begin{align}
x_2+2x_3-2x_4&=2\\
x_2&=2-2x_3+2x_4
\end{align}
</math>

and from row 1 we have,

:<math>
\begin{align}
x_1+2x_3-x_4&=1\\
x_1&=1-2x_3+x_4.
\end{align}
</math>

Therefore we have two null vectors,

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
-2\\
-2\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

and

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

as well as a particular solution

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

Therefore the solution is

:<math>
\mathbf{x}=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
+s
\begin{bmatrix}
-2\\
-2\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
+t
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

There are an infinite number of solutions.
statement_html:
The augmented matrix below for a linear system is put in reduced row echelon form with row operations. Write one of the following:

  • the solution if it is unique

  • all solutions if there are more than one

  • state that there are no solutions.

(e)

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cccc}1 & 0 & 2 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 2 & -2 \end{array}\right.\left| \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
The augmented matrix below for a linear system is put in reduced row echelon form with row operations. Write one of the following:
* the solution if it is unique
* all solutions if there are more than one
* state that there are no solutions.

'''(e)'''
:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cccc}1 & 0 & 2 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 2 & -2 \end{array}\right. \left| \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right]
</math>
